It is important to understand the molecular mechanisms that regulate plant adaptations to space.  cosmic radiation.  Cosmic radiation .

Several spaceflight experiments have examined the global transcriptional changes of plants grown on the International Space Station . Until recently, lighted habitats for plant experimentation were limited . For ease of handling and setup, several experiments were carried out in Biological Research In Canisters .
Some experiments have examined the transcriptional response of plants to partial g levels . These types of experiments can inform us on plant responses to extraterrestrial habitats .
Ground reference experiments were carried out in the ERM-2 at NASA-ARC, using flight build spares and matching environmental parameters to the flight experiments .

The Arabidopsis genome was sequenced using Illumina HiSeq2500 (125 bp single end reads) Library preparation and Illumina sequencing for RNA and small RNA (sRNA) was carried out .  Hypergeometric distribution hypothesis testing was carried out using the phyper function of the R programming language . overlap between individually analyzed PS and
Seedlings in PS have more disordered growth patterns than in PRR . PS roots are more orderly than PRR roots .

The study was published on October 1, 2013 . The study compared PS and PRR to a combined study to impart increased statistical power . RNA-Seq reads were re-analyzed to impart more statistical power to compare the two experiments .
A consensus sequence, 5’-GGCCCA-3’, was returned as the top result of this query . There were 258 occurrences of this motif in 174 unique genes (15.6% of total input genes)

The downregulated DEGs include 120 genes involved in stress responses . They are primarily involved in regulating stress responses and those involved in abiotic stresses . The functions of these downregulated TFs are distinct with limited overlap with those of the upregulated TF .

Microgravity masks the induction of genes in the space environment . Stress response-related genes were upregulated in 1 <em>g in spaceflight experiments compared to ground controls . Microgravity masked genes that respond to many abiotic stresses, including salt and temperature .

miR863 and miR398b are found in Arabidopsis leaves and seedlings . miR319c, miR6b, miRs863-5p and miRs398b-3p were upregulated by repression of translation or DNA methylation . miRNAs are involved in regulation of leaf shape via their interaction with TCP TFs .
Figure 8 shows that a much smaller fraction of genes were differentially regulated in µ <em>g at Day 4 (compared with the DEGs detected at Day 6)

The PS and PRR spaceflight experiments were designed to examine early seedling development and responses to microgravity . To answer these questions, we utilized the EMCS facility with a rotor configuration selected to provide µ <em>g and an onboard 1 <em >g control . Genes upregulated in µ were primarily involved in leaf and shoot development .
Glycomic analysis of spaceflight plant samples have shown changes in cell wall glycans consistent with spaceflight related modification of cell walls .
Genes involved in cell wall modification are overrepresented in our datasets . Cell wall proteins involved in polymer rearrangement during cell elongation were not conserved .
A possible explanation for this observation is that there are differences between 1 <em>g <em >g and µ <em>. grown seedlings in their developmental progression . em>.

The authors conclude that there was no delay in germination under 1 <em>g under microgravity . Longer duration experiments with a finer resolution of time points would be required to fully characterize and understand the regulatory underpinnings for these differences .
